name: plainness
content:
plainness noun [U]
(SIMPLE QUALITY)
Add to word list
Add to word list
the quality of being simple, without decoration or without anything added: There's something about the plainness of the design which I like. Richness of decoration becomes more effective when contrasted with plainness.
More examplesFewer examplesDespite their plainness and their absence of windows, these buildings are not generic white boxes.It's a simple black dress, sleeveless, falling to the floor in unremarkable plainness, except for the rather risqué slit up one side.

plainness noun [U]
(NOT BEAUTIFUL)
the fact of not being beautiful: The only women ever seen there were those whose age and plainness guaranteed respectability.
More examplesFewer examplesCertainly men, like Pompey, had used their looks to further their careers. On the other hand, Cicero was proof that plainness was no disadvantage. Her plainness is actually part of her allure.Rochester is fascinated by Jane's wit and independence, despite her plainness.

plainness noun [U]
(CLEAR QUALITY)
the fact of being clearly understood because of being obvious or being very honest: He told us with great plainness what we had done wrong. To Minnesotans, there is no greater virtue than plainness: being honest, straightforward, unpretentious, plain-spoken.
More examplesFewer examplesThe plainness of the writing, the persuasive speech rhythms, make this one of his most effective poems. Let truth and plainness be the only ornament of your language.Forgive my plainness, but I doubt the truth of this.
